questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of pain in her right knee. The pain is worse at the end of the day and when she walks. She says that it has become difficult for her to walk up the flight of stairs to reach her apartment. She has hypertension. Her sister has rheumatoid arthritis. She drinks two to three beers daily. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and a multivitamin. She appears anxious. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (202 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 135/83 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The right knee is not tender or erythematous; range of motion is limited. Crepitus is heard on flexion and extension of the knee. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,000/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 16 mm/h. An x-ray of the right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular glucocorticoid injections may be administered in patients with severe osteoarthritis to provide short-term pain relief. However, glucocorticoid injections are only indicated if active joint inflammation is present or if nonpharmacological and first-line pharmacological therapy (NSAIDs) do not provide sufficient relief to overcome functional impairment.

B) CORRECT:

A weight loss program is one of the most important general measures to relieve symptoms in patients with osteoarthritis who are overweight or obese. Osteoarthritis is the most common joint disorder in the US. Its incidence increases with age and it commonly affects women over the age of 50 years. The knees are the most commonly affected joints, followed by the hands and hips. Because there are only a few modifiable risk factors in patients with osteoarthritis, including obesity and excessive joint loading or overuse, causal treatment is limited and weight loss is the most effective step in management at this time.

If lifestyle changes (moderate exercise, weight loss) and physical therapy do not improve symptoms or patients have persistent pain, pharmacological treatment may be required. First-line pharmacological treatment consists of NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen).

C) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis is commonly performed in patients with joint effusions to evaluate synovial fluid for crystals (e.g., in crystal-induced arthropathies like gout), leukocytes, and gram-staining (e.g., presence of bacteria in septic arthritis). Patients with both septic arthritis and crystal-induced arthropathies can present with arthralgias and a limited range of motion. However, septic arthritis is usually associated with systemic symptoms (e.g., fever), while both conditions are typically associated with an acute onset, significant swelling, and erythema of the joint. The patient has none of these features.

D) INCORRECT:

Total joint replacement (endoprosthesis) is the treatment of choice in patients with osteoarthritis if conservative and interventional measures fail. But this patient has not received any treatment yet, meaning total joint replacement is not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA typically manifests with joint pain, as in this patient. She might also have a genetic predisposition given her sister's history. However, RA most commonly affects small finger joints, and patients present with symmetrical swelling of the joints and morning stiffness that typically improves with activity. This patient has none of these symptoms, so RA is very unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the preferred method to evaluate soft tissue and cartilage of the knee. MRI can show precisely what damage has been done to the soft tissue within the knee (e.g., meniscus rupture, cruciate ligament injury). MRI is not indicated in the majority of patients with osteoarthritis unless an underlying pathology such as meniscus rupture is suspected.
questions.hint: Knee pain that is worse at the end of the day, crepitus, and limited range of motion in a patient with obesity, combined with osteophytes, subchondral sclerosis, and joint space narrowing on x-ray, indicate osteoarthritis of the knee.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of bilateral knee pain for the past year. She reports that the pain is worse with movement and is relieved with rest. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient says her mother takes leflunomide for a “joint condition.” The patient's medications include metformin and a multivitamin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows pain both in complete flexion and extension, crepitus on joint movement, and joint stiffness and restricted range of motion of both knees. X-ray of the knee joints shows irregular joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes, and several subchondral cysts. There is no reddening or swelling. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular glucocorticoid injections are indicated for the treatment of acute attacks of both rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis. This patient has no signs of an acute attack, such as a sudden exacerbation of pain and worsening joint mobility. Moreover, intraarticular glucocorticoid injections are considered second-line treatment.

B) CORRECT:

The management of osteoarthritis is focused on treating pain, as well as maintaining and improving joint mobility and function. While nonpharmacological treatment approaches include physical therapy, exercise, and patient education (e.g., maintaining a healthy weight), NSAIDs such as ibuprofen are recommended as first-line pharmacological treatment for pain relief. Second-line treatment consists of acetaminophen or intraarticular glucocorticoid injections. Pharmacotherapy should only be used as a short-term treatment in symptomatic patients; long-term therapy is associated with many adverse effects (e.g., renal function impairment, gastric and duodenal ulcers). Surgery is typically indicated if conservative measures fail.
Image Description:

X-ray knees (AP view)

Advanced degenerative changes of the left knee are seen, with marked medial compartment narrowing, surface irregularity (indicated by red line), subchondral sclerosis (example indicated by green overlay), and osteophytes (red overlay). Additional findings include a subchondral cyst (blue overlay) at the lateral edge of the tibia and medial subluxation of the femur (indicated by dashed arrows). Only small intercondylar eminence osteophytes are seen on the right (yellow arrowheads).

C) INCORRECT:

Infliximab is a biological agent used in the immunotherapy of therapy-refractory chronic inflammatory diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis). It is not indicated for the treatment of osteoarthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Celecoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor indicated for analgesic therapy in patients with a history of gastric or gastroduodenal ulcers following treatment with NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen). While celecoxib can be used to treat osteoarthritis, it is less effective than other medications, has an increased risk for cardiovascular side effects, and is more expensive. It is therefore only indicated in patients with gastrointestinal complaints.

E) INCORRECT:

Administration of oral prednisolone is indicated to manage acute attacks of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and to bridge the time until inflammatory processes are adequately controlled by DMARDS. While short-term intraarticular glucocorticoid administration may be used in patients with osteoarthritis, systemic administration is not indicated.

F) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is a DMARD that is effective in reducing inflammation, preventing joint destruction, and slowing disease progression in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Since osteoarthritis is not caused by autoimmune-mediated inflammatory processes, DMARDs are not indicated. This patient's mother is taking leflunomide, a second-line DMARD, as are hydroxychloroquine and sulfasalazine.
questions.hint: This patient with obesity presents with chronic knee pain on exertion, which is relieved with rest. Together with the physical examination and x-ray findings, these features are consistent with osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of left knee pain as well as stiffness upon waking for about 10–15 minutes. The pain is worse after standing a lot at work and when she climbs stairs. There is no history of trauma. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Her mother died of metastatic breast cancer at the age of 65 years. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include atorvastatin, labetalol, and aspirin. Over the past 2 months, she has been taking over-the-counter ibuprofen as needed for the joint pain. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mm Hg. Examination of the left knee shows tenderness on palpation of the anteromedial joint line; there is crepitus and pain with full flexion and extension. Serum uric acid concentration is 8.0 mg/dL, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely finding on imaging of the left knee?

choices.text: Osteophytes with joint space narrowing on x-ray
Calcification of synovia and cartilage on ultrasound
Diffuse lytic-sclerotic bone lesions on x-ray
Joint effusion and pannus on ultrasound
Marginal bone erosions and opaque periarticular soft tissue on x-ray

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In osteoarthritis, patients will show evidence of joint degeneration on imaging. On x-ray, the distinctive features include irregular joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes, and subchondral cysts. A definitive diagnosis is made after consideration of both imaging and clinical findings (e.g., pain on exertion, crepitus on joint movement, restricted range of motion). Treatments include general measures (weight loss in overweight patients, physiotherapy) and analgesics. If conservative and interventional measures fail, endoprosthesis should be considered.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP view)

Marked lateral compartment narrowing (indicated by white lines and arrows) is accompanied by subchondral sclerosis (green overlay) and osteophyte formation (red overlay). Tibial spine osteophytes (example indicated by yellow overlay) are also visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the synovium and cartilage (chondrocalcinosis) is most commonly caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) disease, which typically occurs in elderly patients and usually involves the knee. Chronic CPPD can manifest with features of osteoarthritis (pyrophosphate arthropathy) but more commonly affects the patellofemoral joint and the lateral knee compartment. In contrast, this patient has involvement of the medial knee compartment. Also, a patient with osteoarthritis due to CPPD would have had a history of recurrent attacks of acute CPPD. Osteoarthritis unrelated to CPPD would not be associated with calcification of the synovium or cartilage.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (AP view)

Calcification (green overlay) is seen within the menisci and articular hyaline cartilage of the medial and lateral compartments of the knee.

The chondrocalcinosis was the result of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate disease (CPPD).

C) INCORRECT:

Diffuse lytic-sclerotic bone lesions on x-ray can be seen in breast cancer that has metastasized to bone. This patient has a positive family history of breast cancer and knee pain but does not have signs of inflammation (she has a normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate and no knee swelling) or any clinical features for breast cancer, such as a palpable breast mass or axillary lymphadenopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Joint effusion and pannus formation are classic findings of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can cause joint pain and early morning stiffness. However, morning stiffness associated with RA typically lasts longer than 30 minutes, and the pain, which improves with movement, is usually reduced in the evening. Furthermore, RA typically causes an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and manifests more commonly as oligoarthritis of small joints of the hand rather than monoarthritis of a large joint, such as the knee. Pannus formation is not seen with osteoarthritis.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP view)

Diffuse osteopenia is accompanied by uniform joint space narrowing (indicated by the yellow line), severe erosive changes, and valgus deformity. Secondary changes of osteoarthritis can be seen, including osteophytosis (examples indicated by the red overlay) and subchondral sclerosis (green overlay).

E) INCORRECT:

Marginal bony erosions and opacification of periarticular soft tissue (gouty tophi) are findings of chronic gout, which can occasionally involve the knee and result in chronic joint pain due to secondary osteoarthritis. This patient has many risk factors for gout, including hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and obesity. However, the patient would have hyperuricemia, unlike the normal uric acid concentration seen here, and there would be a past history of recurrent attacks of acute inflammatory gout preceding the onset of joint pain. Osteoarthritis unrelated to gout is not associated with marginal erosions or periarticular soft tissue opacification.
Image Description:

X-ray of a left foot (AP and lateral views)

Joint space narrowing of the first metatarsophalangeal joint with multiple spiky periosteal appositions (green overlay). Both the first metatarsal bone and the first proximal phalanx also show the characteristic “punched-out” lesions (green arrowheads). There is marked soft tissue swelling on the lateral border of the foot (red overlay).
questions.hint: This patient most likely has osteoarthritis, as indicated by her presentation of joint pain that worsens upon movement, morning stiffness < 30 minutes, localization to a knee, age (> 55 years), crepitus, normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and obesity.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive pain and stiffness of the fingers of her right hand that is worse at the end of the day. She works as a hairdresser and has to take frequent breaks to rest her hand. Over the past 2 weeks, she has been taking ibuprofen as needed for the joint pain. Two weeks ago, she completed a course of oral antibiotics for a urinary tract infection. She has hypertension for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide. Her sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. She drinks one to two beers daily and occasionally more on weekends. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling, joint-line tenderness, and decreased range of motion of the right first carpometacarpal joint as well as the second and fourth distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. Discrete, hard, mildly tender swellings are palpated over the second and fourth distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for these findings?

choices.text: Monosodium urate crystal precipitation in the joints
Bacterial infection of the joint space
Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal precipitation in the joints

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gout is caused by the precipitation of monosodium urate crystals in the joints. Gout typically manifests as an acute attack of intense pain and inflammation and usually affects a single joint of the lower extremity (especially the first metatarsophalangeal joint). While she is at risk of developing gout (thiazide diuretic, alcohol consumption), her exam is typical of another disease process.

B) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis can cause pain, joint-line tenderness, swelling, and decreased range of motion. While it is important to consider in the differential, the onset is typically acute, and signs of local inflammation (erythema, warmth of affected joints) would be expected. This patient's physical examination suggests an alternative mechanism.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the joints, as seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), results in the destruction and erosion of joint cartilage. RA generally affects the small hand joints but is usually symmetric and worse with inactivity (> 30 minutes of morning stiffness). This patient does not have evidence of joint inflammation (warmth, erythema), and her physical examination is more typical of another disease process.

D) CORRECT:

Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative condition characterized by pain and stiffness that worsens with activity. OA can affect any joint but frequently affects the knees, hips, and hand joints. Of the hand joints, the proximal interphalangeal and DIP joints are most commonly involved, whereas the metacarpophalangeal joints are typically spared. The Heberden nodes seen in this patient are a characteristic sign of OA.

E) INCORRECT:

Pseudogout is caused by precipitation of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints and typically manifests as recurrent episodes of acute or subacute inflammatory arthritis, usually affecting a solitary large joint. This patient lacks signs of inflammation (erythema and warmth of the joint) and her physical examination is typical of another disease process.
questions.hint: This patient presents with asymmetric oligoarthritis. The bony hard swellings on the dorsal aspect of the distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) suggest a specific etiology.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of progressively worsening pain in her knees and fingers. The knee pain is worse when she walks for longer than 30 minutes. When she wakes up in the morning, her fingers and knees are stiff for about 15 minutes. She cannot recall any trauma to the joints. She was treated with amoxicillin following a tick bite 2 years ago. She is otherwise healthy and only takes a multivitamin and occasionally acetaminophen for the pain. She drinks one to two glasses of wine daily. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 133/78 mm Hg. Examination of the lower extremities shows mild genu varum. Range of motion of both knees is limited; there is palpable crepitus. Complete flexion and extension elicit pain. Tender nodules are present on the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arthropathy due to gout is often acute, asymmetric, and usually involves a single joint (e.g., the great toe or a knee). Although this patient has a few risk factors for gout (e.g., advanced age, obesity, alcohol consumption), examination in gout would show an acutely red, tender, inflamed joint, with decreased range of motion and pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Lyme arthritis is a late manifestation of untreated Lyme disease, developing months (rarely, as late as 2 years) after a tick bite. Lyme arthritis usually causes effusion and mild pain in a single joint, most often the knee, but can affect multiple joints as well and can persist for several years. Although this patient sustained a past tick bite, which could have infected her with Borrelia burgdorferi, she was already treated with amoxicillin, the first-line therapy for Lyme disease. Additionally, she shows no extraarticular signs of the condition. Lastly, Lyme arthritis does not cause crepitus, genu varum, and interphalangeal nodes.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient presents with symmetrical small and large joint pain and stiffness, which would be seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), she has several features that are not consistent with this diagnosis. In patients with RA, morning stiffness of joints characteristically lasts for > 30 minutes, the joint pain and stiffness are relieved with activity, the DIP joints are not affected, and constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, night sweats) are often present. Moreover, the characteristic hand deformities from long-standing RA are swan-neck deformity and Boutonniere deformity as opposed to the interphalangeal joint nodes seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms characteristic of osteoarthritis (OA): joint pain that worsens with ambulation/weight-bearing, joint stiffness < 30 minutes after prolonged immobility, decreased range of motion (due to osteophytes), palpable crepitus of both knees, genu varum (due to medial cartilage loss), and nodules on the DIP (Heberden nodes) and PIP (Bouchard nodes). Furthermore, this patient has multiple risk factors for OA, including female sex, obesity, and age > 55 years.

X-ray of the involved joints would most likely show decreased joint space, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis (areas of increased bone density caused by unequal load-bearing).

E) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis generally has an acute onset, involves a single joint, and is characterized by fever, joint pain, signs of inflammation (erythema, edema, warmth), and a restricted range of joint motion. It is also typically associated with a distant infection (e.g., abscess), IV drug abuse, or immunosuppression. This patient's findings are inconsistent with septic arthritis.

F) INCORRECT:

Pseudogout or calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition (CPPD) disease is a paroxysmal joint inflammation due to calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition. CPPD is often asymptomatic, but acute CPPD can manifest with episodic pain in a single joint characterized by severe pain, inflammation, and joint disability. Chronic CPPD can cause progressively worsening pain affecting large and small joints, without signs of acute inflammation on examination, like this patient. However, chronic CPPD is uncommon and the characteristic interphalangeal joint nodes seen in this patient would not be present in CPPD.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are consistent with the most common joint disorder in the US, which most frequently affects the knee.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of pain and stiffness in her fingers and knees. The stiffness lasts for about 10 minutes after she wakes up in the morning. She also reports that her knee pain is worse in the evening. She drinks one glass of wine daily. Her only medication is acetaminophen. She is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination shows firm nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers of both hands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudogout is joint inflammation due to calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition. Chronic CPPD can cause progressively worsening pain affecting large and small joints. However, the nodules seen in this patient would not be present in CPPD.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) predominantly occurs among women and can affect both large and small joints. It presents as a symmetrical arthropathy with joint pain and early morning stiffness and can cause rheumatoid nodules in the affected small joints, as seen here. However, in patients with RA, morning joint stiffness characteristically lasts for > 30 minutes, and distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) are not as frequently affected.

C) INCORRECT:

Gout can cause joint pain and firm nodular swellings at the affected joints (gouty tophi). This patient also has a few risk factors for gout (e.g., advanced age, obesity, alcohol consumption). However, gout arthropathy is typically acute, asymmetric, and monoarticular, unlike this patient's chronic, symmetric polyarthritis with early morning stiffness.

D) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis causes joint pain. However, it has an acute onset, typically affects a single joint, and is characterized by signs of inflammation (erythema, edema, warmth), unlike in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms characteristic of osteoarthritis (OA). She has pain in weight-bearing joints (knees) that is worse in the evening (due to ambulation during the day). After prolonged immobility, she experiences joint stiffness lasting < 30 minutes. She also has distal interphalangeal joint nodules (Heberden's nodes). Obesity and advanced age are known risk factors for OA.
questions.hint: X-ray of the involved joints would most likely show decreased joint space, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive pain and stiffness of the fingers of her right hand. The stiffness is worse at the end of the day. She recently retired after working for 28 years as a typist at a data entry firm. Physical examination shows swelling, joint-line tenderness, and decreased range of motion of the first metacarpophalangeal joint and the distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. Discrete, hard, mildly tender nodules are palpated over the 2nd and 4th distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. An x-ray of her right hand shows narrowing of the interphalangeal joint spaces with subchondral sclerosis and osteophytes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Monosodium urate crystal precipitation in the joints
Bacterial infection of the joint space
Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal precipitation in the joints

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Monosodium urate crystal precipitation in the joints causes gout, which is associated with hyperuricemia and classically manifests as acute pain and inflammation affecting a single joint of the lower extremity (especially the first metatarsophalangeal joint). Risk factors for gout include thiazide diuretic use and alcohol consumption, neither of which is seen in this patient. The involvement of multiple finger joints and absence of inflammation (e.g., erythema, warmth) seen in this patient make gout very unlikely.
Image Description:

Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Monosodium urate crystals are needle-shaped and appear yellow when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer. If their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer, they appear blue. The underlying physical principle is called negative birefringence.

Detection of negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis of gout.

B) INCORRECT:

Bacterial infection of the joint space is characteristic of septic arthritis, which can also cause pain, joint-line tenderness, swelling, and decreased range of motion. Septic arthritis is usually acute, asymmetric, monoarticular, and accompanied by signs of inflammation (e.g., erythema, warmth in the affected joint, leukocytosis). The polyarticular and chronic nature of this woman's symptoms, along with the absence of fever and risk factors (e.g., IV drug use), make septic arthritis unlikely in this patient.
Image Description:

Synovial fluid predominantly shows neutrophils.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the joints, as seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), results in the destruction and erosion of joint cartilage. RA commonly involves the hand joints, but it is usually symmetric, does not affect the DIP joints, and is worse with inactivity (> 30 minutes of morning stiffness). The subchondral sclerosis and osteophytes seen on this patient's imaging are also atypical for RA, which is instead characterized by joint space erosions and cysts on imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal deposition disease (e.g., pseudogout) typically manifests as recurrent episodes of acute or subacute inflammatory arthritis, usually affecting a solitary large joint (e.g., the knee). This patient lacks signs of inflammation (e.g., erythema, warmth of the joint) and chondrocalcinosis on x-ray, making this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals with typical rhomboid shapes. They appear blue when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer and yellow when their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer (positive birefringence). The overall birefringence of CPP crystals is weak compared to monosodium urate crystals.

E) CORRECT:

Osteoarthritis (OA) is a form of degenerative arthritis characterized by pain and stiffness that worsens with activity. In this patient, it is likely related to her 28-year history of working as a typist. While OA can affect any joint, it frequently affects the knees and hand joints (most commonly the DIP and PIP). The Heberden nodes seen in this patient are a characteristic sign of OA, which can also manifest with Bouchard nodes. Typical imaging findings include joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, and osteophyte formation.
Image Description:

Nodular thickening of the distal interphalangeal joints (DIPJ) and proximal interphalangeal joints (PIPJ) can be seen.

This appearance is characteristic of bony swellings caused by osteophyte formation in osteoarthritis. At the DIPJ these are called “Heberden nodes” (best seen here on the right middle finger and both index fingers), and at the PIPJ they are called “Bouchard nodes” (best seen here on the right middle finger).
questions.hint: This patient presents with asymmetric, polyarticular arthritis and Heberden nodes (tender nodules over the DIP joints). The osteophytes seen on imaging are consistent with a specific diagnosis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of bilateral knee pain for the past year. The pain is worse with movement and is relieved with rest. Physical examination shows crepitus, pain, and decreased range of motion with flexion and extension of both knees. There is no warmth, redness, or swelling. X-rays of both knees show irregular joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and subchondral cysts. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone can be used to treat inflammatory arthritis, such as rheumatoid arthritis. This patient lacks any signs of inflammatory arthritis (e.g., erythema, warmth of the affected joint), and the chronicity and bilateral nature of his symptoms make osteoarthritis much more likely. In patients with severe pain due to osteoarthritis, intra-articular glucocorticoids can be used but the systemic administration of glucocorticoids is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is a DMARD that reduces inflammation, prevents joint destruction, and slows disease progression in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis. This patient's history and x-ray findings (subchondral cysts, osteophytes, and joint space narrowing) suggest osteoarthritis, not rheumatoid arthritis. Because osteoarthritis is not an inflammatory process, methotrexate would have no therapeutic benefit.

C) CORRECT:

NSAIDs such as naproxen are used as first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with osteoarthritis. Because of the degenerative nature of osteoarthritis, management should be focused on treating pain as well as maintaining and improving joint mobility and function. Other medications used for the treatment of osteoarthritis include acetaminophen, topical capsaicin, and intra-articular glucocorticoids. Glucocorticoid injections are usually only indicated for acute, severe pain in which NSAIDs have not been effective.
Image Description:

X-ray knees (AP view)

Advanced degenerative changes of the left knee are seen, with marked medial compartment narrowing, surface irregularity (indicated by red line), subchondral sclerosis (example indicated by green overlay), and osteophytes (red overlay). Additional findings include a subchondral cyst (blue overlay) at the lateral edge of the tibia and medial subluxation of the femur (indicated by dashed arrows). Only small intercondylar eminence osteophytes are seen on the right (yellow arrowheads).

D) INCORRECT:

Allopurinol is a reversible xanthine oxidase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine into uric acid. Allopurinol is used as a maintenance therapy for patients with gout, which is associated with hyperuricemia and typically has an acute presentation with asymmetric joint swelling and pain (classically affecting the big toe). This man's subacute and bilateral symptoms are consistent with osteoarthritis, for which allopurinol is not effective.

E) INCORRECT:

Celecoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor that is most commonly used as analgesic therapy in patients with gastric or gastroduodenal ulcers because of the drug's reversible and selective inhibition of cyclooxygenase 2 without affecting cyclooxygenase 1. Although celecoxib can also be used to treat osteoarthritis, it is less effective and more expensive than other medications, and it has an increased risk for cardiovascular side effects. Therefore, celecoxib is only indicated in patients with gastrointestinal concerns, which this patient does not report.

F) INCORRECT:

Infliximab is a biological agent used for the treatment of refractory inflammatory arthritis, such as rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis. This patient does not have signs of local inflammation such as erythema, swelling, and warmth in the affected joints, making inflammatory arthritis extremely unlikely. Infliximab is not indicated for the treatment of osteoarthritis.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation (chronic knee pain on exertion that is relieved with rest), physical examination findings (crepitus, decreased range of motion), and x-ray findings are consistent with osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 9-month history of pain and stiffness in the right knee. He reports that the stiffness lasts approximately 10 minutes after waking up and that the pain is worse in the evening. There is no history of trauma. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Examination of the right knee shows tenderness in the anteromedial joint line and crepitus during knee movement. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 15 mm/h and a serum uric acid concentration of 6.9 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely finding on imaging of the right knee?

choices.text: Osteophytes and narrowing of the joint-space
Marginal bony erosions and opacification of periarticular soft tissue
Loculated epiphyseal cyst with thinning of the overlying cortex
Bony ankylosis and bone proliferation at the entheses
Calcification of the synovium and cartilage

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Osteoarthritis (OA) is caused by articular cartilage degeneration, which results in narrowing of the joint space. Unlike inflammatory degenerative arthritides, which cause uniform joint space narrowing, OA is associated with focal joint space narrowing that is most prominent in regions where stress is concentrated (e.g., medial compartment of the knee, superolateral aspect of the hip). Subsequently, reactive bone formation and trabecular compression cause subchondral sclerosis, and entry of synovial fluid into the bone forms subchondral cysts. To limit damage to the bone, remnants of the degenerating cartilage undergo endochondral ossification. This results in the formation of osteophytes at the margin of the joint space.

In patients with OA of the hand, these osteophytes can be palpated as bony spurs (Heberden nodes, Bouchard nodes) on examination.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP view)

Marked lateral compartment narrowing (indicated by white lines and arrows) is accompanied by subchondral sclerosis (green overlay) and osteophyte formation (red overlay). Tibial spine osteophytes (example indicated by yellow overlay) are also visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Marginal bony erosions and opacification of periarticular soft tissue (gouty tophi) are findings of chronic gout, which can occasionally involve the knee and result in chronic joint pain due to secondary osteoarthritis. However, the patient would have hyperuricemia, unlike the normal uric acid levels seen here, and there would be a past history of recurrent attacks of acute inflammatory gout preceding the onset of joint pain. Osteoarthritis unrelated to gout would not be associated with marginal erosions or periarticular soft tissue opacification.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (left: AP view; right: lateral view) of a patient with a history of gout

An eccentric lesion involves the lateral femoral condyle (green overlay) and adjacent soft tissues (red overlay). A sclerotic margin is seen along part of the lesion (arrowheads).

C) INCORRECT:

Periarticular osteopenia and pannus formation are classic findings in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can cause joint pain and early morning stiffness. However, morning stiffness associated with RA typically lasts longer than 30 minutes and the pain, which improves with movement, is usually less in the evening. Furthermore, RA typically causes an elevated ESR and manifests more commonly as oligoarthritis of small joints of the hand rather than monoarthritis of a large joint such as the knee. Periarticular osteopenia and pannus formation are not seen with osteoarthritis.
Image Description:

X-ray hands (PA view)

There is generalized periarticular osteopenia (example indicated by green overlay) and narrowing of several metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joint spaces (example indicated by green line). The marked deformity of the wrists is the result of numerous carpal, base of metacarpal, and radiocarpal erosions (red lines). Erosive scalloping (example indicated by yellow line) also involves the radioulnar joint.

The radiographic findings are typical of rheumatoid arthritis with advanced wrist involvement.

D) INCORRECT:

A large, loculated epiphyseal cyst (soap-bubble appearance) with thinning of the overlying cortex describes the radiographic appearance of a giant cell tumor (osteoclastoma), which often affects the knee joint. However, an osteoclastoma typically occurs in younger patients (20–40 years) and it would not be expected to cause joint line tenderness or crepitus. Patients with osteoarthritis would develop subchondral cysts, but such cysts are neither loculated nor associated with thinning of the overlying bone cortex.
Image Description:

X-ray left knee (AP view) of a 23-year-old patient with a giant cell tumor (osteoclastoma)

A lucent lesion in the proximal tibia (green overlay) has a bubbly appearance (examples indicated by outlines) and well-defined nonsclerotic margins. The cortex shows endosteal scalloping (examples indicated by arrowheads). The growth plate is closed and the lesion extends to the subarticular bone.

Giant cell tumor is one of several bone lesions that can have a bubbly appearance. Most giant cell tumors are eccentrically located, although large lesions may appear central. They are typically located at the ends of the long bones in the region of the closed growth plate. Some giant cell tumors contain aneurysmal bone cyst components.

E) INCORRECT:

Bony ankylosis and bone proliferation at the entheses (enthesophytes) are characteristic of certain seronegative arthritides (e.g., psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis). However, while psoriatic arthritis typically affects small joints of the hands and would be associated with a history of scaly cutaneous plaques, ankylosing spondylitis would affect the spine. In patients with osteoarthritis, bone proliferation occurs within the joint capsule at the ends of joint lines rather than at entheses, and bony ankylosis would not be expected.
Image Description:

X-ray hands (PA view)

Asymmetric advanced arthritis involves the left hand, with ankylosis of several proximal and distal interphalangeal (PIP and DIP) joints (examples indicated by green overlay) along with multiple flexion deformities. Marginal erosions are present at the bases of the small finger proximal phalanx and thumb distal phalanx (red overlay). Central subchondral erosions and proliferative changes with a gull-wing deformity are seen at the right ring finger DIP joint.

Also shown is an illustration of a pencil-in-cup deformity (not present here), which can occur in psoriatic arthritis and several other inflammatory arthritides.

Advanced degenerative changes additionally involve multiple left carpal and metacarpal joints.

F) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the synovium and cartilage (chondrocalcinosis) is most commonly caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) disease, which typically occurs in elderly patients and usually involves the knee. Chronic CPPD can manifest with features of osteoarthritis (pyrophosphate arthropathy), but it more commonly affects the patellofemoral joint and the lateral knee compartment, unlike here, where there is involvement of the medial knee compartment. Also, a patient with osteoarthritis due to CPPD would have had a past history of recurrent attacks of acute CPPD. Osteoarthritis unrelated to CPPD would not be associated with calcification of the synovium or cartilage.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (AP view)

Calcification (green overlay) is seen within the menisci and articular hyaline cartilage of the medial and lateral compartments of the knee.

The chondrocalcinosis was the result of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate disease (CPPD).
questions.hint: Pain that is worse in the evening (due to ambulation during the day), brief morning stiffness (< 30 minutes), a normal ESR, involvement of the medial knee compartment, and the presence of crepitus with joint movement suggest non-inflammatory degenerative arthritis (osteoarthritis) as the cause of this patient's chronic monoarticular pain. Advanced age and obesity are risk factors for primary osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of gradually worsening pain in his right groin. The pain increases during and after physical exercise, especially when climbing stairs. After waking up in the morning, the right hip feels stiff for up to 20 minutes. He has not sustained any recent trauma. His father died of lung cancer at the age of 78 years. He has hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. He drinks one 12-oz beer daily. Current medications are valsartan and tamsulosin. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 73/min, and blood pressure is 129/80 mm Hg. Examination of the right hip shows a limited internal rotation; there is crepitus, and pain with full flexion and extension. The right inguinal area is soft without any palpable masses. Muscle strength is 5/5 bilaterally. Leukocyte count is 4,500/mm3, erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 16 mm/h, and serum uric acid concentration is 7.3 mg/dL. An x-ray of this patient's right hip is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Marginal bone erosions and opaque periarticular soft tissue

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Marginal bone erosions and opaque periarticular soft tissue (gouty tophi) are findings of chronic gout, which can occasionally involve the hip, causing progressive joint destruction and leading to secondary osteoarthritis. This patient has multiple risk factors for gout, such as hypertension, obesity, and alcohol consumption. However, patients with gout typically have hyperuricemia, unlike the normal uric acid levels seen here, and a history of recurrent attacks of acute inflammatory gout preceding the onset of joint pain. Osteoarthritis unrelated to gout is not associated with marginal erosions or periarticular soft tissue opacification.
Image Description:

X-ray of a left foot (AP and lateral views)

Joint space narrowing of the first metatarsophalangeal joint with multiple spiky periosteal appositions (green overlay). Both the first metatarsal bone and the first proximal phalanx also show the characteristic “punched-out” lesions (green arrowheads). There is marked soft tissue swelling on the lateral border of the foot (red overlay).

B) INCORRECT:

Cartilage calcification, also known as chondrocalcinosis, is most commonly caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) disease. Chronic CPPD disease typically affects individuals > 60 years of age and can manifest with features of osteoarthritis (pyrophosphate arthritis), which are seen here. However, patients with osteoarthritis due to CPPD characteristically have a history of recurrent attacks of acute CPPD. Osteoarthritis unrelated to CPPD is not associated with calcification of the cartilage.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (AP view)

Calcification (green overlay) is seen within the menisci and articular hyaline cartilage of the medial and lateral compartments of the knee.

The chondrocalcinosis was the result of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate disease (CPPD).

C) CORRECT:

OA is a chronic noninflammatory degenerative condition in which chronic mechanical stress and an age-related decrease in proteoglycans cause joint cartilage to lose elasticity and become friable. This process, in turn, leads to degeneration and inflammation of the cartilage, which is visible on x-ray as irregular joint space narrowing (most prominent in regions where stress is concentrated, like the superolateral aspect of the hip) and subchondral sclerosis. Other findings of OA that can be seen on x-ray are osteophytes and subchondral cysts. A definitive diagnosis is made after consideration of both imaging and clinical findings (e.g., pain on exertion, crepitus on joint movement, restricted range of motion). Treatment includes general measures (e.g., physiotherapy, weight loss in patients who are overweight) and analgesics. If conservative and interventional measures fail, endoprosthesis should be considered.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP view)

Marked lateral compartment narrowing (indicated by white lines and arrows) is accompanied by subchondral sclerosis (green overlay) and osteophyte formation (red overlay). Tibial spine osteophytes (example indicated by yellow overlay) are also visible.

D) INCORRECT:

Cartilage erosions and bone demineralization on x-ray are consistent with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can manifest with morning stiffness and joint pain. However, the morning stiffness in RA typically lasts > 30 minutes and the joint pain improves with activity. Furthermore, RA typically causes an elevated ESR and manifests more commonly as polyarthritis of small joints of the hand rather than monoarthritis of a large joint such as the hip. Although some of the x-ray findings of RA and OA can overlap because of the chronic joint destruction common to both, erosions of cartilage and bone demineralization are not generally seen in patients with OA.
Image Description:

X-ray hands (PA view)

There is generalized periarticular osteopenia (example indicated by green overlay) and narrowing of several metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joint spaces (example indicated by green line). The marked deformity of the wrists is the result of numerous carpal, base of metacarpal, and radiocarpal erosions (red lines). Erosive scalloping (example indicated by yellow line) also involves the radioulnar joint.

The radiographic findings are typical of rheumatoid arthritis with advanced wrist involvement.

E) INCORRECT:

Diffuse lytic bone lesions on x-ray suggest osteolytic bone metastasis, which can be caused by metastatic lung cancer. Although this patient's positive family history is a risk factor for developing lung cancer, no typical clinical findings are seen, such as cough, dyspnea, and constitutional symptoms. Prostate cancer can also metastasize to the bone; however, it typically leads to osteoblastic rather than osteolytic lesions.
Image Description:

X-ray femur (AP view) of a patient with bronchogenic carcinoma

A lytic cortical lesion (red overlay) involves the middle third of the femur.

Metastases can be lytic, sclerotic, or mixed-density lesions. Osteolytic lesions are the most common and are usually metastases from carcinomas of the kidney, lung, breast, gastrointestinal tract, or thyroid gland.
questions.hint: The combination of chronic joint pain that worsens with movement and is associated with limited range of motion, morning stiffness lasting < 30 minutes, and crepitus suggest osteoarthritis (OA). Risk factors for OA include age > 55 years and obesity.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man with progressive left hip pain comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. One year ago, he was diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the left hip. Since then, he has had an 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss after changing to a vegetarian diet, regular swimming, and physical therapy. The pain worsens when he climbs stairs, which makes it increasingly difficult for him to reach his apartment located on the second floor. Over the last few weeks, he gradually increased the frequency of diclofenac intake but says that even a daily intake does not provide complete pain relief. He asks for a treatment that will lead to a long-term improvement of his symptoms. He has no history of major medical illness. His only other medication is pantoprazole. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He is 179 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Physical examination of the left hip shows crepitus, a limited internal rotation, and pain with full flexion and extension. An x-ray of the left hip shows joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis and cysts. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopic hip debridement may be used in the treatment of a labral tear or femoroacetabular impingement of the hip, but it is generally not recommended in the treatment of either hip or knee OA because of the lack of evidence supporting its benefits.

B) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular glucocorticoid injections may be administered in patients with severe OA to provide short-term pain relief. However, they are not a long-term option. Therefore, another step in management is more appropriate for this patient, who asks for long-term improvement of his symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Walking aids, such as a walker, cane, or crutches (used on the healthy, unaffected side) may be used in patients with hip OA and severe pain and/or as fall prevention. However, there is no evidence that walking aids reduce pain in patients with hip OA, nor are walking aids a good option for patients like this one, who are physically active.

D) INCORRECT:

Fentanyl patches have a high analgesic potency and are used to treat insufficiently controlled chronic pain, which is seen in this patient. While nonopioid analgesics in conjunction with nonpharmacologic measures are an important part of pain management in patients with OA, opioids should generally be avoided, especially as a long-term solution, because of potential adverse effects (e.g., dizziness, nausea, addictive potential).

E) CORRECT:

Total hip arthroplasty is recommended in patients with hip OA who have experienced inadequate relief using conservative measures (physical therapy, exercise, weight loss, pain medication), there is evidence of advanced OA (e.g., severe pain, radiological signs of osteoarthritis), and symptoms impact the patient's daily life significantly, as seen here. In addition, this patient has no evidence of contraindications to surgery (e.g., active infection, major medical illness).

Intraarticular glucocorticoid injections can be used as second-line therapy for short-term pain relief (e.g., while waiting for surgery).
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view)

Marked narrowing of the weight-bearing regions of the acetabulofemoral joint spaces (yellow lines) is accompanied by femoral head and acetabular sclerosis (green overlay), subchondral cyst formation (examples indicated by white dashed outlines), and osteophytes (examples indicated by red overlay). The femoral heads show superolateral migration and loss of normal sphericity.
questions.hint: Long-term improvement of osteoarthritis (OA) of the hip joint requires treating the cause rather than the symptoms.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man reports that he has had pain in both shoulders for most of the past 6 months. It is constant, worse on the right, and associated with aching and stiffness in the upper arms. He reports no headache, jaw or arm claudication, scalp tenderness, or diplopia.
On physical examination, he is afebrile, and his blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg in both arms. He has difficulty with both active and passive range of motion of both shoulders, including external rotation and abduction. Crepitus is evident on movement of both shoulders. He has full range of motion in both hips. The temporal arteries are equal, not prominent or beaded, and are nontender bilaterally; he has equal radial pulses in both hands.
Laboratory evaluation shows an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 25 mm/hr (reference range, 0–17).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain MRI of the right shoulder

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient most likely has shoulder osteoarthritis (OA), which can be assessed with shoulder radiography. Although MRI is more sensitive than radiography for identifying features of OA, radiography is more appropriate and cost-effective than MRI for initial evaluation of a patient suspected of having OA of the shoulder.

B) INCORRECT:

A temporal artery biopsy is used to diagnose giant-cell arteritis. However, this diagnosis is unlikely in the absence of headache, jaw claudication, prominent constitutional symptoms, or loss of vision. Temporal artery biopsy or initiation of prednisone at the high doses used for giant-cell arteritis (1 mg/kg/day) is therefore not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

A temporal artery biopsy is used to diagnose giant-cell arteritis. However, this diagnosis is unlikely in the absence of headache, jaw claudication, prominent constitutional symptoms, or loss of vision. Temporal artery biopsy or initiation of prednisone at the high doses used for giant-cell arteritis (1 mg/kg/day) is therefore not indicated.

D) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has shoulder osteoarthritis (OA), which can be assessed with shoulder radiography. Although MRI is more sensitive than radiography for identifying features of OA, radiography is more appropriate and cost-effective than MRI for initial evaluation of a patient suspected of having OA of the shoulder.

Key learning point: The finding of crepitus on examination of the shoulders is most consistent with a diagnosis of shoulder osteoarthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

One of the main differential diagnoses in this case is polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR). PMR should be suspected in older patients who have morning stiffness (a defining feature of an inflammatory arthritis), pelvic or shoulder-girdle pain, and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Because PMR is a diagnosis of exclusion, clinical evidence must be assembled from a variety of imperfect tests to rule out other possible explanations for a patient’s shoulder pain. In this case, the patient has shoulder crepitus, an ESR that is only mildly elevated, and no report of morning stiffness. These factors suggest a diagnosis other than PMR; therefore, initiation of prednisone at the doses typically used for PMR (10–20 mg) is not indicated.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman presents with a one-year history of progressively worsening bilateral hand pain. She notes that her hands look somewhat deformed, particularly over the distal interphalangeal joints, and are stiff for about 30 minutes every morning. She is right-handed. The pain is greatest at the end of the day. She reports no history of erythematous or swollen joints or painful swelling of an entire finger.
Her medical history includes obesity, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease, with a baseline creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1). She has no history of psoriasis or inflammatory bowel disease.
Examination of the hands shows bony enlargement over her second and third right-distal interphalangeal joints bilaterally, and no swelling or erythema over her metacarpophalangeal or proximal interphalangeal joints. The wrists are normal. Examination of the knees reveals intact range of motion; there are no effusions, but crepitus is present bilaterally upon active and passive flexion and extension.
Laboratory testing shows an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 30 mm/hr (reference range, 1–25) and a C-reactive protein level of 2.0 mg/liter (0.08–3.10).
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s age puts her at risk for either osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis, but her presentation (brief morning stiffness, distal interphalangeal joint involvement with bony enlargement [Heberden nodes], and no evidence of inflammatory arthritis) is indicative of osteoarthritis. Topical 1% diclofenac gel is a reasonable option for treating hand osteoarthritis in this patient. Topical nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) have minimal systemic absorption when used within prescribing guidelines (the systemic exposure is at least an order of magnitude lower than with oral NSAIDs), and they tend to be at least partially effective and very well tolerated.

In a patient with chronic kidney disease, systemic NSAIDs such as oral ibuprofen should be avoided.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial pharmacologic treatment for pain associated with hand osteoarthritis in a patient with chronic kidney disease is topical 1% diclofenac gel.

B) INCORRECT:

In a patient with chronic kidney disease, systemic NSAIDs such as oral ibuprofen should be avoided.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids should be reserved for patients who have substantial inflammation. An erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 30 mm/hr is not unusual in a healthy older adult. In a patient with a very low suspicion for inflammatory arthritis based on history and examination, laboratory testing for markers of inflammation is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Drugs that are used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, such as leflunomide, are not indicated for osteoarthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Drugs that are used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, such as methotrexate, are not indicated for osteoarthritis. Methotrexate is also contraindicated in patients with more advanced kidney disease.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man reports a 7-week history of progressive pain and swelling in his left knee that developed after he returned from a sightseeing trip to Cambodia. The pain is exacerbated by walking and is relieved by rest. There is no locking of the knee. During the past year, the patient has noted morning stiffness affecting his legs that resolves within 15 minutes after waking up. He reports no other recent trauma, injury, or illness.
On physical examination, his temperature is 36.9°C, his blood pressure is 132/72 mm Hg, his heart rate is 88 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute. There is a large left-knee effusion without warmth or erythema. Varus deformity of the left knee is noted, and range of motion in extension or flexion is limited by pain. No joint-line tenderness is found. A McMurray test is negative for any clicking in the medial compartment. The remainder of the musculoskeletal examination is normal.
Plain radiography of the left knee reveals a large effusion, narrowing of the medial joint space, and osteophytes arising from the patellofemoral and tibiofemoral joints.
Arthrocentesis is performed, and a 25-mL synovial-fluid sample is clear yellow with a leukocyte count of 300 per mm3 and a differential of 92% lymphocytes and 8% neutrophils.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis, caused by bacterial infection, results in purulent-appearing synovial fluid, a leukocyte count that is always inflammatory and usually in the range of 50,000 to 150,000 per mm3, and a strong neutrophil predominance.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis is unlikely in the absence of inflammatory synovial fluid. Rheumatoid arthritis also usually features morning stiffness lasting >60 minutes and most often involves the small joints of the hands and feet.

C) INCORRECT:

Pes anserinus pain syndrome occurs as an overuse syndrome of the knee and is often exacerbated by pes planus (flat feet). Pain can be difficult for patients to localize symptomatically, but physical examination identifies focal tenderness at the pes anserine, a convergence of three tendons (sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus) at the proximal medial tibia, 2 to 3 cm distal to the knee joint line.

D) INCORRECT:

Crystalline arthropathies manifest with inflammatory synovial fluid along with the presence of monosodium urate or calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals. Some patients with osteoarthritis have deposition of CPP in the cartilage of affected joints (known as chondrocalcinosis) and are therefore at risk for acute CPP crystal arthritis (pseudogout), but the fluid in an attack of acute CPP crystal arthritis is inflammatory.

E) CORRECT:

The patient’s symptoms are typical of an osteoarthritis flare. The principal symptom of osteoarthritis is pain, which usually increases with activity and improves with rest. In more advanced cases, pain may become persistent and occur at rest or at night. Morning stiffness that resolves in less than 30 minutes is also common in patients with osteoarthritis, although some patients describe recurrence of stiffness after a period of inactivity, known as the gelling phenomenon.

The joints most commonly affected in osteoarthritis are the knees, the hips, and the distal interphalangeal and first carpometacarpal joints of the hands. Examination of an affected knee may be normal but is often notable for tenderness on palpation at the joint line, limited range of motion, crepitus, and/or joint effusion. The major radiographic features include joint-space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes, and subchondral cysts.

There is a broad differential diagnosis for acute or subacute monoarticular knee pain and swelling. If a patient’s symptoms, findings on physical examination, and radiographic evidence are suggestive of an osteoarthritic flare, arthrocentesis can be done to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other causes, such as a septic arthritis or crystalline arthropathy.

The synovial fluid in patients with osteoarthritis is typically noninflammatory, with a leukocyte count up to 2000 per mm3, a predominance of lymphocytes, and <25% polymorphonuclear leukocytes.

Key learning point: Joint effusions related to osteoarthritis typically have noninflammatory fluid with leukocyte counts in the range of 200 to 2000 cells per mm3.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman reports a 5-month history of pain at the base of her right thumb. The pain is exacerbated by activities that involve pinching or grasping with the thumb. She has not noticed swelling or redness. She has taken maximal over-the-counter doses of naproxen and ibuprofen, each for several weeks, with minimal relief.
Physical examination reveals tenderness over the volar aspect of the base of the thumb but no swelling or erythema in the hand. Pain is induced by rotating the thumb while applying mild axial pressure. No tenderness is evident along the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons. A Finkelstein test is negative.
A radiograph of the hand reveals narrowing of the first carpometacarpal space, with sclerosis and osteophyte formation.
Which one of the following initial management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical trapeziectomy is reserved for patients who do not respond to more-conservative therapies, including splinting, analgesics, and glucocorticoid injection.

B) CORRECT:

Osteoarthritis of the carpometacarpal joint (also known as the trapeziometacarpal joint) is a common cause of pain at the base of the thumb. Instability and loss of both motion and strength may occur as the osteoarthritic changes progress. The pain is accentuated by repeated pinching and grasping. Typical findings on radiographs include narrowing of the joint with sclerotic changes, spur formation, and lateral subluxation of the base of the first metacarpal joint.

Managing pain from hand osteoarthritis follows the same principles as managing pain from osteoarthritis in other sites, beginning with more conservative approaches and proceeding to more aggressive therapies only if necessary. Patients with carpometacarpal osteoarthritis often benefit initially from splinting of the carpometacarpal joint with a neoprene or rigid orthosis (a thumb spica splint). This conservative approach is the preferred first option in a patient whose pain has not been controlled by nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

Key learning point: Conservative management for carpometacarpal osteoarthritis that is not responsive to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs involves a first carpometacarpal orthosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Intra-articular injection of hyaluronate is generally ineffective in the hands.

D) INCORRECT:

Although weight loss is strongly recommended as part of the treatment for knee and hip osteoarthritis, it would not be expected to help patients with hand osteoarthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Although intra-articular injection of glucocorticoids is often offered to patients with osteoarthritis of the hand, an initial trial of splinting is typically favored first.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man with hypertension and stage 3 chronic kidney disease reports a one-year history of pain in his right hand. He describes the pain as a mild, dull ache that worsens when he uses his right hand, especially in turning doorknobs or keys. In the morning he has stiffness in his hands for about 30 minutes. He reports no known injury to the area, numbness, or paresthesias. His medications include donepezil, docusate, amlodipine, and a multivitamin.
His physical examination is notable for slight tenderness and prominence of the base of the thumb. The pain is reproduced while rotating the base of the thumb with an axial pressure. His wrist has normal flexion and extension. Forced ulnar deviation of the hand at the wrist causes no tenderness. He has multiple bony prominences over the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints, which are not tender on palpation.
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s pain?

choices.text: Glucocorticoid injection into the first carpometacarpal joint
Measurement of the serum levels of rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibody
Ibuprofen 800 mg 3 times daily with food

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although glucocorticoid injections are frequently performed, studies indicate that they provide little or no benefit.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical referral should be reserved for the most severe cases, and evidence for benefit is anecdotal.

C) INCORRECT:

The medical history and physical examination can usually rule out other causes of thumb pain, such as de Quervain tenosynovitis and rheumatoid arthritis; tests for rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibody are not needed.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic kidney disease of stage 3 or worse is a contraindication to the chronic use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.

E) CORRECT:

Osteoarthritis of the hands can be an important source of disability with increasing age. Hand osteoarthritis may involve the distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden nodes), the proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s nodes), or the first carpometacarpal joint. Tasks requiring thumb opposition, such as turning keys, can be difficult in patients with first-carpometacarpal osteoarthritis. Pain is reproduced while rotating the base of the thumb with an axial pressure (the “grind test”), and visible “squaring” at the base of the thumb is typical. The medical history and physical examination can usually rule out other causes of thumb pain, such as de Quervain tenosynovitis and rheumatoid arthritis; tests for rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibody are not needed.

Treatment of osteoarthritis in the first carpometacarpal joint is supportive, consisting of occupational therapy and splints.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of chronic pain and squaring at the base of the thumb in an older patient is osteoarthritis of the first carpometacarpal joint.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old woman reports a one-year history of pain in both hands. The pain is constant, associated with stiffness, and especially severe at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints. Her second DIP on the left, which is erythematous, is bothering her most. She also notes that her DIPs are becoming “deformed,” as she recalls her mother’s had been in older age. She reports no clear worsening of symptoms in the morning or with activity.
Physical examination reveals deformities and lateral bony prominences at several DIP and proximal interphalangeal joints in both hands, and her second DIP on the left is also tender and erythematous. Her metacarpophalangeal joints are normal. No other joint pain or discomfort is evident, except for crepitus in both knees. Her skin examination is normal, as is the rest of her physical examination.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s hand discomfort?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Distal interphalangeal pain in an older patient with associated features of bony prominences in the lateral DIP and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints is consistent with a diagnosis of osteoarthritis (OA). A familial predisposition has been reported for osteoarthritis involving the fingers.

Heberden nodes (bony prominences from OA at the DIP joints) and Bouchard nodes (at the PIP joints) are the classic findings of hand OA. When these nodes initially develop, they can become inflamed and may be mistaken for an inflammatory arthritis.

Key learning point: When examining a patient with arthritis involving the distal interphalangeal joints, one should consider the possible diagnoses of psoriatic arthritis, tophaceous gout, and osteoarthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis rarely affects the DIP joints.

C) INCORRECT:

Both gout and psoriatic arthritis can affect the DIP joints. However, the lateral bony prominences are characteristic of OA, whereas soft-tissue swelling is more prominent in gout and psoriatic arthritis. In addition, this patient has no other joint or skin findings suggestive of gout or psoriasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Both gout and psoriatic arthritis can affect the DIP joints. However, the lateral bony prominences are characteristic of OA, whereas soft-tissue swelling is more prominent in gout and psoriatic arthritis. In addition, this patient has no other joint or skin findings suggestive of gout or psoriasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Multicentric reticulohistiocytosis is a rare disease that can also cause a destructive DIP arthritis; however, it is generally associated with papules, nodules, and (often) constitutional symptoms.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with obesity (BMI, 32), type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and obstructive sleep apnea presents for follow-up of chronic bilateral knee pain. For the past 5 years, he has had progressive anterior knee pain that is worse with weight-bearing; he is now having persistent pain at night and at rest, and he is no longer able to walk more than a few hundred feet because of the pain. He has tried physical therapy, acetaminophen, ibuprofen, and intra-articular glucocorticoid injections with minimal relief. Last year, he lost 4.5 kg with dietary modification, which resulted in only mild improvement in his knee pain.
Physical examination of the knees reveals varus deformities, without palpable effusion. There is tenderness along the joint line as well as crepitus. Standing knee radiographs demonstrate severe loss of joint space in the medial and lateral compartments with osteophytes and subchondral sclerosis, consistent with severe osteoarthritis.
Which one of the following next steps in management is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Refer for knee arthroscopy and debridement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is evidence supporting duloxetine for pain management in mild-to-moderate cases of osteoarthritis; however, surgery is more appropriate in a patient with end-stage OA.

B) INCORRECT:

Although weight loss is important in reducing load on the knees and should be recommended in patients with knee OA, this intervention would not offer meaningful symptomatic relief in a patient with severe joint damage. In addition, this patient has a BMI of 32; bariatric surgery in patients with obesity-related comorbidities is typically not indicated until the BMI is ≥35. Thus, bariatric surgery referral would not be recommended in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopy and debridement for symptomatic knee OA, although commonly performed, is not supported by randomized trials and is not recommended for severe knee OA.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has chronic pain from severe knee osteoarthritis (OA), a degenerative disease of cartilage and joint breakdown for which disease-modifying therapies are not available. In cases of severe OA in which nonoperative options have failed, total knee replacement should be considered to control pain and restore function. This patient’s medical comorbidities should not preclude this procedure.

Key learning point: In patients with severe osteoarthritis symptoms that are refractory to nonsurgical interventions, the most appropriate next step in management is referral for total joint arthroplasty.

E) INCORRECT:

Pain management with opioids is not recommended for knee OA because of the lack of demonstrated efficacy as well as the long-term risks related to chronic opioid use.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman reports pain, swelling, and warmth in her right knee 18 hours after receiving a methylprednisolone-lidocaine injection to manage chronic osteoarthritis in that knee. The symptoms began about 6 hours after the injection and have not improved. She is otherwise healthy and reports no fever, chills, or other systemic symptoms.
She is afebrile and has normal vital signs. She has more tenderness to palpation over the medial and lateral joint lines than she did before the injection and a new modest-size knee effusion, but her examination findings are otherwise stable. Her range of motion is limited in both flexion and extension, and passive assistance causes pain. There is no laxity with ligamentous testing.
Joint aspiration yields 25 mL of nonbloody cloudy yellow fluid. Laboratory testing of the aspirate reveals 12,000 leukocytes per mm3 with 95% polymorphonuclear cells. Gram stain is negative. Crystal analysis with compensated polarized light microscopy shows abundant intra- and extracellular crystals with polymorphic appearance and both positive and negative birefringence.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Apply ice, and initiate treatment with ibuprofen
Arrange for orthopedic arthroscopic lavage of the knee

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Although complications from intra-articular glucocorticoid injections are uncommon, up to 2% of patients experience postinjection flares, which are characterized by an increase in joint pain, swelling, tenderness, and warmth over the joint. The symptoms typically begin 6 to 12 hours after the injection and can last for 24 to 48 hours. The flares are thought to be the result of a synovitis caused by glucocorticoid crystals, which may stimulate inflammatory cells through pattern-recognition motifs such as toll-like receptors (analogous to the proposed mechanism of uric acid crystals in acute gouty arthritis). They have also been reported to occur after viscosupplementation injection. A postinjection flare is best treated with rest, ice, and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.

Aspiration of the joint is sometimes (but not always) performed to rule out infection, especially if the symptoms do not respond to antiinflammatory treatment or if they persist for more than 48 hours. However, the probability of infection in this patient was low, given that symptoms began so soon after the injection.

Key learning point: A common complication of an intra-articular glucocorticoid injection is postinjection flare.

B) INCORRECT:

Orthopedic drainage of the joint is not indicated in this scenario, given the absence of identifiable infectious arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy is not indicated in this scenario, given the absence of identifiable infectious arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

If aspiration reveals crystals of uric acid or calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPP), then colchicine could be considered for the management of acute gout or acute CPP crystal arthritis (pseudogout), respectively. In this case, the polymorphic crystals represent the recently injected glucocorticoid, not gout or acute CPP crystal arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy is not indicated in this scenario, given the absence of identifiable infectious arthritis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-year history of progressively worsening pain in her knees and fingers. The knee pain is worse when she walks for longer than 30 minutes. When she wakes up in the morning, her fingers and knees are stiff for about 15 minutes. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the lower extremities shows mild genu varum. Range of motion of both knees is limited; there is palpable crepitus. Complete flexion and extension elicit pain. Tender nodules are present on the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints of the index, ring, and little fingers bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arthropathy due to gout is often acute, asymmetric, and usually involves a single joint (e.g., the great toe or a knee). Although this patient has a few risk factors for gout (e.g., advanced age, obesity, alcohol consumption), examination in gout would show an acutely red, tender, inflamed joint, with decreased range of motion and pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient presents with symmetrical small and large joint pain and stiffness, which would be seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), she has several features that are not consistent with this diagnosis. In patients with RA, morning stiffness of joints characteristically lasts for > 30 minutes, the joint pain and stiffness are relieved with activity, the DIP joints are not affected, and constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, night sweats) are often present.
