Moreover, the characteristic hand deformities from long-standing RA are swan-neck deformity and Boutonniere deformity as opposed to the interphalangeal joint nodes seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms characteristic of osteoarthritis (OA): joint pain that worsens with ambulation/weight-bearing, joint stiffness < 30 minutes after prolonged immobility, decreased range of motion (due to osteophytes), palpable crepitus of both knees, genu varum (due to medial cartilage loss), and nodules on the DIP (Heberden nodes) and PIP (Bouchard nodes). Furthermore, this patient has multiple risk factors for OA, including female sex, obesity, and age > 55 years.

X-ray of the involved joints would most likely show decreased joint space, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis (areas of increased bone density caused by unequal load-bearing).

Key learning point: Osteoarthritis is characterized by joint pain that worsens with activity, brief morning stiffness, crepitus, decreased range of motion, and bony nodules at the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints.

D) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis generally has an acute onset, involves a single joint, and is characterized by fever, joint pain, signs of inflammation (erythema, edema, warmth), and a restricted range of joint motion. It is also typically associated with a distant infection (e.g., abscess), IV drug abuse, or immunosuppression. This patient's findings are inconsistent with septic arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Pseudogout or calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition (CPPD) disease is a paroxysmal joint inflammation due to calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition. CPPD is often asymptomatic, but acute CPPD can manifest with episodic pain in a single joint characterized by severe pain, inflammation, and joint disability. Chronic CPPD can cause progressively worsening pain affecting large and small joints, without signs of acute inflammation on examination, like this patient. However, chronic CPPD is uncommon and the characteristic interphalangeal joint nodes seen in this patient would not be present in CPPD.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are consistent with the most common joint disorder in the US, which most frequently affects the knee.

questions.text: A previously healthy 61-year-old man comes to the office because of bilateral knee pain for the past year. The pain is worse with movement and is relieved with rest. Physical examination shows crepitus, pain, and decreased range of motion with flexion and extension of both knees. There is no warmth, redness, or swelling. X-rays of both knees show irregular joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and subchondral cysts. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone can be used to treat inflammatory arthritis, such as rheumatoid arthritis. This patient lacks any signs of inflammatory arthritis (e.g., erythema, warmth of the affected joint), and the chronicity and bilateral nature of his symptoms make osteoarthritis much more likely. In patients with severe pain due to osteoarthritis, intra-articular glucocorticoids can be used but the systemic administration of glucocorticoids is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is a DMARD that reduces inflammation, prevents joint destruction, and slows disease progression in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis. This patient's history and x-ray findings (subchondral cysts, osteophytes, and joint space narrowing) suggest osteoarthritis, not rheumatoid arthritis. Because osteoarthritis is not an inflammatory process, methotrexate would have no therapeutic benefit.

C) CORRECT:

NSAIDs such as naproxen are used as first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with osteoarthritis. Because of the degenerative nature of osteoarthritis, management should be focused on treating pain as well as maintaining and improving joint mobility and function. Other medications used for the treatment of osteoarthritis include acetaminophen, topical capsaicin, and intra-articular glucocorticoids. Glucocorticoid injections are usually only indicated for acute, severe pain in which NSAIDs have not been effective.
Image Description:

X-ray knees (AP view)

Advanced degenerative changes of the left knee are seen, with marked medial compartment narrowing, surface irregularity (indicated by red line), subchondral sclerosis (example indicated by green overlay), and osteophytes (red overlay). Additional findings include a subchondral cyst (blue overlay) at the lateral edge of the tibia and medial subluxation of the femur (indicated by dashed arrows). Only small intercondylar eminence osteophytes are seen on the right (yellow arrowheads).

D) INCORRECT:

Allopurinol is a reversible xanthine oxidase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine into uric acid. Allopurinol is used as a maintenance therapy for patients with gout, which is associated with hyperuricemia and typically has an acute presentation with asymmetric joint swelling and pain (classically affecting the big toe). This man's subacute and bilateral symptoms are consistent with osteoarthritis, for which allopurinol is not effective.

E) INCORRECT:

Celecoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor that is most commonly used as analgesic therapy in patients with gastric or gastroduodenal ulcers because of the drug's reversible and selective inhibition of cyclooxygenase 2 without affecting cyclooxygenase 1. Although celecoxib can also be used to treat osteoarthritis, it is less effective and more expensive than other medications, and it has an increased risk for cardiovascular side effects. Therefore, celecoxib is only indicated in patients with gastrointestinal concerns, which this patient does not report.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation (chronic knee pain on exertion that is relieved with rest), physical examination findings (crepitus, decreased range of motion), and x-ray findings are consistent with osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents with a 9-month history of pain and stiffness in the right knee. He reports that the stiffness lasts approximately 10 minutes after waking up and that the pain is worse in the evening. There is no history of trauma. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Examination of the right knee shows tenderness in the anteromedial joint line and crepitus during knee movement. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 15 mm/h and a serum uric acid concentration of 6.9 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely finding on imaging of the right knee?

choices.text: Osteophytes and narrowing of the joint-space
Marginal bony erosions and opacification of periarticular soft tissue
Bony ankylosis and bone proliferation at the entheses
Calcification of the synovium and cartilage

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Osteoarthritis (OA) is caused by articular cartilage degeneration, which results in narrowing of the joint space. Unlike inflammatory degenerative arthritides, which cause uniform joint space narrowing, OA is associated with focal joint space narrowing that is most prominent in regions where stress is concentrated (e.g., medial compartment of the knee, superolateral aspect of the hip). Subsequently, reactive bone formation and trabecular compression cause subchondral sclerosis, and entry of synovial fluid into the bone forms subchondral cysts. To limit damage to the bone, remnants of the degenerating cartilage undergo endochondral ossification. This results in the formation of osteophytes at the margin of the joint space.

In patients with OA of the hand, these osteophytes can be palpated as bony spurs (Heberden nodes, Bouchard nodes) on examination.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP view)

Marked lateral compartment narrowing (indicated by white lines and arrows) is accompanied by subchondral sclerosis (green overlay) and osteophyte formation (red overlay). Tibial spine osteophytes (example indicated by yellow overlay) are also visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Marginal bony erosions and opacification of periarticular soft tissue (gouty tophi) are findings of chronic gout, which can occasionally involve the knee and result in chronic joint pain due to secondary osteoarthritis. However, the patient would have hyperuricemia, unlike the normal uric acid levels seen here, and there would be a past history of recurrent attacks of acute inflammatory gout preceding the onset of joint pain. Osteoarthritis unrelated to gout would not be associated with marginal erosions or periarticular soft tissue opacification.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (left: AP view; right: lateral view) of a patient with a history of gout

An eccentric lesion involves the lateral femoral condyle (green overlay) and adjacent soft tissues (red overlay). A sclerotic margin is seen along part of the lesion (arrowheads).

C) INCORRECT:

Periarticular osteopenia and pannus formation are classic findings in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can cause joint pain and early morning stiffness. However, morning stiffness associated with RA typically lasts longer than 30 minutes and the pain, which improves with movement, is usually less in the evening. Furthermore, RA typically causes an elevated ESR and manifests more commonly as oligoarthritis of small joints of the hand rather than monoarthritis of a large joint such as the knee. Periarticular osteopenia and pannus formation are not seen with osteoarthritis.
Image Description:

X-ray hands (PA view)

There is generalized periarticular osteopenia (example indicated by green overlay) and narrowing of several metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joint spaces (example indicated by green line). The marked deformity of the wrists is the result of numerous carpal, base of metacarpal, and radiocarpal erosions (red lines). Erosive scalloping (example indicated by yellow line) also involves the radioulnar joint.

The radiographic findings are typical of rheumatoid arthritis with advanced wrist involvement.

D) INCORRECT:

Bony ankylosis and bone proliferation at the entheses (enthesophytes) are characteristic of certain seronegative arthritides (e.g., psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis). However, while psoriatic arthritis typically affects small joints of the hands and would be associated with a history of scaly cutaneous plaques, ankylosing spondylitis would affect the spine. In patients with osteoarthritis, bone proliferation occurs within the joint capsule at the ends of joint lines rather than at entheses, and bony ankylosis would not be expected.
Image Description:

X-ray hands (PA view)

Asymmetric advanced arthritis involves the left hand, with ankylosis of several proximal and distal interphalangeal (PIP and DIP) joints (examples indicated by green overlay) along with multiple flexion deformities. Marginal erosions are present at the bases of the small finger proximal phalanx and thumb distal phalanx (red overlay). Central subchondral erosions and proliferative changes with a gull-wing deformity are seen at the right ring finger DIP joint.

Also shown is an illustration of a pencil-in-cup deformity (not present here), which can occur in psoriatic arthritis and several other inflammatory arthritides.

Advanced degenerative changes additionally involve multiple left carpal and metacarpal joints.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the synovium and cartilage (chondrocalcinosis) is most commonly caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) disease, which typically occurs in elderly patients and usually involves the knee. Chronic CPPD can manifest with features of osteoarthritis (pyrophosphate arthropathy), but it more commonly affects the patellofemoral joint and the lateral knee compartment, unlike here, where there is involvement of the medial knee compartment. Also, a patient with osteoarthritis due to CPPD would have had a past history of recurrent attacks of acute CPPD. Osteoarthritis unrelated to CPPD would not be associated with calcification of the synovium or cartilage.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (AP view)

Calcification (green overlay) is seen within the menisci and articular hyaline cartilage of the medial and lateral compartments of the knee.

The chondrocalcinosis was the result of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate disease (CPPD).
questions.hint: Pain that is worse in the evening (due to ambulation during the day), brief morning stiffness (< 30 minutes), a normal ESR, involvement of the medial knee compartment, and the presence of crepitus with joint movement suggest non-inflammatory degenerative arthritis (osteoarthritis) as the cause of this patient's chronic monoarticular pain. Advanced age and obesity are risk factors for primary osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with left-knee pain that has been worsening for the past year. His BMI is 40 kg/m2. The patient says that he has significant discomfort in his left knee when he walks or stands for long periods and that the pain worsens when he descends a flight of stairs. He is concerned that his right knee may be starting to bother him as well. Bilateral standing radiographs of the knees reveal mild-to-moderate medial joint-space narrowing on the left, but normal findings on the right. What is the most appropriate long-term strategy for preventing progression of this patient's disease process?

choices.text: Consult with an orthopedic surgeon to schedule left total-knee arthroplasty
Start ibuprofen 600 mg two to three times daily
Start physical therapy once a week

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Minimizing activity may reduce pain in the short term but is unlikely to prevent progression.

B) CORRECT:

Weight loss is the best long-term management strategy for patient with osteoarthritis (OA). Obesity is one of the strongest modifiable risk factors for the development of OA. A longitudinal study showed that among people with unilateral knee pain, the risk for contralateral knee osteoarthritis increased by 6.5% for each additional 5 kg of weight. In another study, participants in the highest BMI tertile had 8.6 times the odds of developing radiographic and symptomatic osteoarthritis as participants in the lowest BMI tertile. Weight loss has been shown to reduce knee pain in patients with radiographic OA.

Whether weight loss slows the radiographic progression of OA once it is apparent is unclear. However, in this patient, weight loss has the prospect of reducing pain and reducing the likelihood that OA will develop in the knee that is currently asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic.

Key learning point: In patients with obesity and osteoarthritis of the knees, weight loss should be recommended as a long-term strategy to reduce and prevent worsening of arthritis symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Total-knee arthroplasty is warranted only if osteoarthritis symptoms are severe, and many surgeons would be reluctant to operate on a patient at such a young age or with severe obesity.

D) INCORRECT:

Regular use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs may reduce pain in the short term but is unlikely to prevent progression. In addition, long-term use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents may be associated with adverse effects.

E) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy might help to strengthen the quadriceps muscles but is unlikely to prevent progression unless accompanied by weight loss.
questions.hint: Knee pain during exertion and obesity combined with joint space narrowing on x-ray, indicate osteoarthritis of the knee.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents with 8 months of gradually worsening right knee pain that intensifies with walking and lessens at rest. He denies prolonged morning stiffness. Examination shows a varus alignment of the knee, tenderness along the medial joint line, no notable swelling or warmth, and slightly limited range of motion.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with prolonged morning stiffness, symmetrical joint involvement, and signs of synovitis such as warmth and swelling. The patient's symptoms, including localized knee pain without significant swelling or prolonged stiffness, do not align with rheumatoid arthritis, which is a systemic inflammatory condition.

B) CORRECT:

Osteoarthritis manifests with gradual degeneration of articular cartilage and changes in subchondral bone. The patient's chronic knee pain that worsens with activity and improves with rest suggests a mechanical process. Varus alignment increases load on the medial knee compartment, causing cartilage wear and medial joint line tenderness. The absence of prolonged morning stiffness and inflammatory signs like warmth or swelling supports a non-inflammatory etiology. These findings are typical in older adults with degenerative joint changes.

Key learning point: Chronic knee pain that worsens with activity and is relieved by rest, along with a varus deformity and medial joint line tenderness, is indicative of osteoarthritis, particularly affecting the medial compartment of the knee.
Image Description:

X-ray knees (AP standing view)

Marked bilateral medial compartment joint space narrowing is accompanied by surface irregularity (indicated by red lines), subchondral sclerosis (example indicated by green overlay), and prominent osteophytes (examples indicated by arrowheads). Subluxation of the medial femoral condyles is also seen (indicated by dashed arrows). The lateral compartments show only mild degenerative changes.

C) INCORRECT:

Pes anserine bursitis manifests with tenderness below the medial joint line at the tendon insertion, often with subtle swelling. The patient's tenderness is along the medial joint line, and the varus deformity suggests chronic mechanical load rather than isolated bursal inflammation. The gradual pain worsening with activity supports a mechanical etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

Medial meniscal tears often cause joint line tenderness and may follow a twisting injury, presenting with mechanical symptoms like locking or clicking. The patient's chronic symptoms without a history of injury or mechanical symptoms, along with varus alignment, suggest a degenerative process rather than an acute meniscal tear.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man presents with persistent left knee pain despite using acetaminophen. He has a 5-year history of left knee osteoarthritis and stage 3 chronic kidney disease (eGFR 48 mL/min/1.73 m²). He is concerned about possible medication side effects. He reports difficulty climbing stairs but remains ambulatory. Physical examination shows a cool knee with crepitus and limited range of motion.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to manage his symptoms?

choices.text: Supervised physical therapy and a knee brace

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Total knee replacement is reserved for severe osteoarthritis with significant functional limitation after failed conservative management. This patient, despite persistent pain, maintains ambulation and does not meet criteria for surgery. Conservative treatments, including physical therapy and activity modifications, are indicated initially.

B) CORRECT:

In knee osteoarthritis, especially with concurrent chronic kidney disease, non-pharmacologic interventions are prioritized due to limitations on NSAID use. Supervised physical therapy improves joint stability, range of motion, and muscle strength, reducing stress on the knee and alleviating pain. A knee brace provides mechanical support and offloads stress from degenerative compartments. This approach addresses pain and improves function, aligning with guidelines recommending lifestyle modifications and rehabilitative strategies as initial management for osteoarthritis.

Key learning point: In patients with osteoarthritis and chronic kidney disease, conservative treatments such as splinting and occupational therapy are preferred to avoid the renal risks associated with NSAIDs.

C) INCORRECT:

Opioids are not ideal for this elderly patient with chronic kidney disease due to risks of sedation, cognitive impairment, and falls. Reduced renal function can impair opioid elimination, leading to accumulation and increased side effects. Alternative therapies with better safety profiles are preferred for chronic osteoarthritis pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Intra-articular hyaluronic acid injections aim to restore joint lubrication and reduce pain in knee osteoarthritis. However, evidence of significant clinical benefit is lacking, and this intervention is typically considered after failure of non-pharmacologic measures and first-line medical therapies. The delayed onset of benefit makes it less suitable for immediate symptom relief.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents with 8 months of progressively worsening right knee pain. She has no significant past medical history. She describes a constant, deep ache that worsens with prolonged standing and improves with rest, and notes brief stiffness after getting up from a chair that resolves within 15 minutes. Examination reveals crepitus on flexion, mild bony enlargement, and no warmth or erythema (see report).
Knee radiographs: Joint space narrowing and osteophytes
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis is characterized by decreased bone mineral density and increased fracture risk, often asymptomatic until a fracture occurs. This patient's symptoms and radiographic findings, such as joint space narrowing and osteophytes, are more consistent with a degenerative joint process like osteoarthritis, not osteoporosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis usually presents as symmetric polyarthritis with prolonged morning stiffness and systemic symptoms. Radiographs show marginal erosions and periarticular osteopenia. This patient's single joint involvement, brief stiffness, and radiographic findings of joint space narrowing and osteophytes are more indicative of osteoarthritis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's chronic knee pain, which worsens with activity and improves with rest, along with brief stiffness after inactivity, is indicative of osteoarthritis, a common degenerative joint disease in older adults. Examination findings of crepitus and bony enlargement, along with radiographic evidence of joint space narrowing and osteophytes, support this diagnosis. Osteoarthritis involves cartilage degradation and subchondral bone remodeling, leading to these clinical and radiographic features without significant inflammatory signs.

Key learning point: Osteoarthritis is characterized by deep, aching joint pain, stiffness after inactivity, and pain aggravated by activity, distinguishing it from other conditions like osteoporosis and osteomyelitis.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP view)

Marked lateral compartment narrowing (indicated by white lines and arrows) is accompanied by subchondral sclerosis (green overlay) and osteophyte formation (red overlay). Tibial spine osteophytes (example indicated by yellow overlay) are also visible.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteomyelitis typically presents with acute localized pain, swelling, warmth, and systemic symptoms like fever. Radiographs often show lytic lesions or periosteal reactions. This patient's chronic knee pain, absence of inflammatory signs, and radiographic findings of joint space narrowing and osteophytes suggest a degenerative process rather than an infection.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents with a two-year history of gradually worsening discomfort in both hands. She describes achy, stiff fingers, especially after prolonged activity, with stiffness resolving within 10 minutes. Physical examination shows firm, non-tender swellings over the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints with normal range of motion elsewhere. She denies any significant swelling of the wrists or metacarpophalangeal joints (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



WBC
7.5 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


ESR
3 mm/h
2 - 10 mm/h


C-reactive peptide
2 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L



Radiographs of hands: Narrowed joint spaces and small osteophytes in the affected joints
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis that typically involves the wrists and metacarpophalangeal joints, not the distal interphalangeal joints. It presents with prolonged morning stiffness and elevated inflammatory markers, which are absent here. The radiographic findings of joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation suggest a degenerative process, not the erosive changes seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic arthritis often presents with skin lesions, nail pitting, or dactylitis, none of which are noted here. It is an inflammatory arthritis with prolonged stiffness and elevated inflammatory markers. Radiographs typically show erosive changes, not the joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudogout, or calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease, usually presents with acute inflammatory episodes and chondrocalcinosis on radiographs, neither of which are present. The patient's symptoms and radiographic findings are consistent with a degenerative process, not the acute inflammation typical of pseudogout.

D) CORRECT:

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the gradual loss of articular cartilage and bone remodeling. The patient presents with activity-related joint pain and stiffness that resolves quickly, typical of osteoarthritis. The firm, non-tender swellings over the distal interphalangeal joints (Heberden nodes) and proximal interphalangeal joints (Bouchard nodes) are classic findings. Radiographs show narrowed joint spaces and osteophyte formation, indicative of chronic cartilage degradation. Normal inflammatory markers, such as ESR and C-reactive protein, further support a degenerative rather than inflammatory process.

Key learning point: Hand osteoarthritis commonly affects the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints and is characterized by non-tender hard nodules, such as Heberden's nodes, with normal inflammatory markers.
Image Description:

Nodular thickening of the distal interphalangeal joints (DIPJ) and proximal interphalangeal joints (PIPJ) can be seen.

This appearance is characteristic of bony swellings caused by osteophyte formation in osteoarthritis. At the DIPJ these are called “Heberden nodes” (best seen here on the right middle finger and both index fingers), and at the PIPJ they are called “Bouchard nodes” (best seen here on the right middle finger).

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 9-month history of pain and stiffness in his right knee. He reports that the stiffness lasts about 10 minutes after waking and that the pain is worse in the evening. There is no history of trauma. He is 175 cm tall and weighs 102 kg; BMI is 33. On examination, there is tenderness in the anteromedial joint line of the right knee and crepitus with movement. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 15 mm/h (0–10) and a serum uric acid concentration of 411 μmol/L (208–400). Which one of the following is the most likely finding on imaging of the right knee?

choices.text: Osteophytes and narrowing of the joint-space.
Marginal bony erosions and opacification of periarticular soft tissue.
Bony ankylosis and bone proliferation at the entheses.
Calcification of the synovium and cartilage.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Osteoarthritis (OA) is caused by articular cartilage degeneration, which results in narrowing of the joint space. Unlike inflammatory degenerative arthritides, which cause uniform joint space narrowing, OA is associated with focal joint space narrowing that is most prominent in regions where stress is concentrated (e.g., medial compartment of the knee, superolateral aspect of the hip). Subsequently, reactive bone formation and trabecular compression cause subchondral sclerosis, and entry of synovial fluid into the bone forms subchondral cysts. To limit damage to the bone, remnants of the degenerating cartilage undergo endochondral ossification. This results in the formation of osteophytes at the margin of the joint space.

In patients with OA of the hand, these osteophytes can be palpated as bony spurs (Heberden nodes, Bouchard nodes) on examination.

Key learning point: Osteoarthritis is characterized on imaging by joint space narrowing and osteophyte (bone spur) formation, most commonly affecting weight-bearing joints.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP view)

Marked lateral compartment narrowing (indicated by white lines and arrows) is accompanied by subchondral sclerosis (green overlay) and osteophyte formation (red overlay). Tibial spine osteophytes (example indicated by yellow overlay) are also visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Marginal bony erosions and opacification of periarticular soft tissue (gouty tophi) are findings of chronic gout, which can occasionally involve the knee and result in chronic joint pain due to secondary osteoarthritis. However, the patient would have hyperuricemia, unlike the normal uric acid levels seen here, and there would be a past history of recurrent attacks of acute inflammatory gout preceding the onset of joint pain. Osteoarthritis unrelated to gout would not be associated with marginal erosions or periarticular soft tissue opacification.

C) INCORRECT:

Bony ankylosis and bone proliferation at the entheses (enthesophytes) are characteristic of certain seronegative arthritides (e.g., psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis). However, while psoriatic arthritis typically affects small joints of the hands and would be associated with a history of scaly cutaneous plaques, ankylosing spondylitis would affect the spine. In patients with osteoarthritis, bone proliferation occurs within the joint capsule at the ends of joint lines rather than at entheses, and bony ankylosis would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the synovium and cartilage (chondrocalcinosis) is most commonly caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) disease, which typically occurs in elderly patients and usually involves the knee. Chronic CPPD can manifest with features of osteoarthritis (pyrophosphate arthropathy), but it more commonly affects the patellofemoral joint and the lateral knee compartment, unlike here, where there is involvement of the medial knee compartment. Also, a patient with osteoarthritis due to CPPD would have had a past history of recurrent attacks of acute CPPD. Osteoarthritis unrelated to CPPD would not be associated with calcification of the synovium or cartilage.

E) INCORRECT:

Periarticular osteopenia and pannus formation are classic findings in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can cause joint pain and early morning stiffness. However, morning stiffness associated with RA typically lasts longer than 30 minutes and the pain, which improves with movement, is usually less in the evening. Furthermore, RA typically causes an elevated ESR and manifests more commonly as oligoarthritis of small joints of the hand rather than monoarthritis of a large joint such as the knee. Periarticular osteopenia and pannus formation are not seen with osteoarthritis.
questions.hint: Pain that is worse in the evening (due to ambulation during the day), brief morning stiffness (< 30 minutes), a normal ESR, involvement of the medial knee compartment, and the presence of crepitus with joint movement suggest non-inflammatory degenerative arthritis (osteoarthritis) as the cause of this patient's chronic monoarticular pain. Advanced age and obesity are risk factors for primary osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes comes to your clinic with left knee pain that has been worsening over the past year. His BMI is 40. He reports significant discomfort in his left knee when walking or standing for long periods, and the pain worsens when descending stairs. He is also concerned that his right knee may be starting to bother him. Bilateral standing radiographs of the knees show mild-to-moderate medial joint-space narrowing on the left and normal findings on the right. Which one of the following is the most appropriate long-term strategy to prevent progression of his disease process?

choices.text: Consult with an orthopedic surgeon to schedule left total-knee arthroplasty.
Start physical therapy once a week.
Start ibuprofen 600 mg two to three times daily.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Total-knee arthroplasty is warranted only if osteoarthritis symptoms are severe, and many surgeons would be reluctant to operate on a patient at such a young age or with severe obesity.

B) INCORRECT:

Minimizing activity may reduce pain in the short term but is unlikely to prevent progression.

C) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy might help to strengthen the quadriceps muscles but is unlikely to prevent progression unless accompanied by weight loss.

D) CORRECT:

Weight loss is the best long-term management strategy for patient with osteoarthritis (OA). Obesity is one of the strongest modifiable risk factors for the development of OA. A longitudinal study showed that among people with unilateral knee pain, the risk for contralateral knee osteoarthritis increased by 6.5% for each additional 5 kg of weight. In another study, participants in the highest BMI tertile had 8.6 times the odds of developing radiographic and symptomatic osteoarthritis as participants in the lowest BMI tertile. Weight loss has been shown to reduce knee pain in patients with radiographic OA.

Whether weight loss slows the radiographic progression of OA once it is apparent is unclear. However, in this patient, weight loss has the prospect of reducing pain and reducing the likelihood that OA will develop in the knee that is currently asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic.

Key learning point: In patients with obesity and osteoarthritis of the knees, weight loss should be recommended as a long-term strategy to reduce and prevent worsening of arthritis symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Regular use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs may reduce pain in the short term but is unlikely to prevent progression. In addition, long-term use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents may be associated with adverse effects.
questions.hint: Knee pain during exertion and obesity combined with joint space narrowing on x-ray, indicate osteoarthritis of the knee.

questions.text: A previously healthy 61-year-old man comes to your clinic with a one-year history of bilateral knee pain. The pain worsens with movement and improves with rest. On examination, there is crepitus, pain, and decreased range of motion with flexion and extension of both knees. There is no warmth, redness, or swelling. X-rays of both knees show irregular joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and subchondral cysts. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone can be used to treat inflammatory arthritis, such as rheumatoid arthritis. This patient lacks any signs of inflammatory arthritis (e.g., erythema, warmth of the affected joint), and the chronicity and bilateral nature of his symptoms make osteoarthritis much more likely. In patients with severe pain due to osteoarthritis, intra-articular glucocorticoids can be used but the systemic administration of glucocorticoids is not recommended.

B) CORRECT:

NSAIDs such as naproxen are used as first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with osteoarthritis. Because of the degenerative nature of osteoarthritis, management should be focused on treating pain as well as maintaining and improving joint mobility and function. Other medications used for the treatment of osteoarthritis include acetaminophen, topical capsaicin, and intra-articular glucocorticoids. Glucocorticoid injections are usually only indicated for acute, severe pain in which NSAIDs have not been effective.

Key learning point: NSAIDs such as naproxen are first-line pharmacologic therapy for osteoarthritis to relieve pain and improve joint function.
Image Description:

X-ray knees (AP view)

Advanced degenerative changes of the left knee are seen, with marked medial compartment narrowing, surface irregularity (indicated by red line), subchondral sclerosis (example indicated by green overlay), and osteophytes (red overlay). Additional findings include a subchondral cyst (blue overlay) at the lateral edge of the tibia and medial subluxation of the femur (indicated by dashed arrows). Only small intercondylar eminence osteophytes are seen on the right (yellow arrowheads).

C) INCORRECT:

Allopurinol is a reversible xanthine oxidase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine into uric acid. Allopurinol is used as a maintenance therapy for patients with gout, which is associated with hyperuricemia and typically has an acute presentation with asymmetric joint swelling and pain (classically affecting the big toe). This man's subacute and bilateral symptoms are consistent with osteoarthritis, for which allopurinol is not effective.

D) INCORRECT:

Celecoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor, which is most commonly used as analgesic therapy in patients with peptic ulcer disease due to the drug's reversible and selective inhibition of cyclooxygenase 2, without affecting cyclooxygenase 1. Celecoxib can be used to treat osteoarthritis, but it is more expensive than other pain-management medications, while offering only comparable efficacy. This makes it less cost-effective for patients who do not have gastrointestinal risk factors.

E) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is used to slow disease progression in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which usually begins at an earlier age and typically affects small joints before involving large joints. The pain of RA is associated with prolonged morning stiffness and is often relieved with movement. Although x-rays of affected joints in RA can reveal subchondral cysts, the joint space narrowing is typically uniform, and osteophytes would not be expected. Instead, the characteristic features are periarticular osteopenia and marginal erosions.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation (chronic knee pain on exertion that is relieved with rest), physical examination findings (crepitus, decreased range of motion), and x-ray findings are consistent with osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease presents with a 4-day history of progressive right knee pain and swelling. She describes the pain as aching, worse after walking, and improving with rest. Morning stiffness lasted 15 minutes today. Examination shows crepitus, mild effusion, and no erythema. Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with classic osteoarthritis features: age > 65 years, mechanical pain pattern, brief morning stiffness, and crepitus. Because she has chronic kidney disease, topical NSAIDs are preferred over oral NSAIDs to avoid further renal impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral ibuprofen is contraindicated in patients with chronic kidney disease because oral NSAIDs can worsen renal function.

C) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis is not routinely indicated for osteoarthritis unless there is diagnostic uncertainty about septic arthritis or inflammatory arthritis. The clinical presentation strongly suggests osteoarthritis without red flags that would be indications for synovial fluid analysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Tramadol is reserved for patients who cannot tolerate or have insufficient relief with NSAIDs. They are not used as initial therapy and should be used cautiously in older adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular corticosteroid injections provide effective local relief but are not first-line therapy.
